Article.ArticleTitle: Modified Method for Trapping and Analyzing <sup>15</sup>N in NO Released from Soils.

AbstractText: <sup>15</sup>N isotope tracing is an effective and direct approach to investigate sources of nitric oxide (NO) formed in soils. However, NO is highly reactive and rapidly converted to nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) in the presence of ozone, making it impossible to directly measure <sup>15</sup>N in NO. Various wet-chemical methods for conversion of NO to nitrite (NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup>) and nitrate (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>) have been proposed for <sup>15</sup>N analysis in high-concentration NO sources, such as combustion processes. In contrast, NO concentrations in the soil surface-near air are usually small (ppbv-range), posing major challenges to conversion efficiency and blank correction. Here, we present a modified method in which NO is oxidized quantitatively to NO<sub>2</sub> by chromium trioxide (CrO<sub>3</sub>), before conversion to NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> and NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> in an alkaline hydrogen peroxide (H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) solution. A denitrifier method was used to reduce NO<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup> and NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> in the trapping solution quantitatively to nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O) for subsequent <sup>15</sup>N analysis. NO trapping efficiencies of >85% were obtained with 50 ppb NO in a 0.5 L min<sup>-1</sup> air stream bubbling through a solution of 1.2 M H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> and 0.5 M NaOH. In a laboratory test with distinct <sup>15</sup>NO abundances, the overall precision was 0.29‰ (δ-values) for natural abundance NO and 0.13 atom % for labeled NO, suggesting that our method can be used for both natural abundance studies and <sup>15</sup>N labeling experiments. In a soil incubation experiment with <sup>15</sup>NH<sub>4</sub>NO<sub>3</sub>, NH<sub>4</sub><sup>15</sup>NO<sub>3</sub>, or Na<sup>15</sup>NO<sub>2</sub> amendments, we found distinct <sup>15</sup>N abundances in NO, indicating that our method is well suited to investigate NO sources in soils.
